text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single narrow column of vernacular text filling lower two-thirds of the page; full-width rectangular miniature occupying the entire upper third under a two-line red rubric; wide margins on all sides; text does not wrap around the image.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata in brown ink with red rubrics; professional execution with regular letterforms, extensive use of litterae notata, abbreviations and consistent vertical pen-strokes

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for heavenly background, setting off the miracle scene; green draperies for Christ-figure and supplicants to indicate vitality; pale blue on the central figure to denote importance; red used sparingly for decorative dots and rubric echoing in the miniature; flat application with white highlights on drapery and flesh; pigments remain vivid with minimal darkening of the white lead under drawing.

features: Flanking groups of standing onlookers create bilateral symmetry
Lower register of kneeling supplicants leads the eye upward to the central figure
Overlapping figures suggest depth without true linear perspective
Architectural framing (arch at left) anchors action

decorative_elements: Double ruled frame in brown ink around miniature
Plain gold leaf background with no diapering

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work in brown ink with varied line weight for contours and facial details
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal hatching in drapery folds, white lead highlights to model volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping rather than coherent linear perspective; spatial depth indicated by diminutive background figures

content_theme.scene_description: A single miracle scene occupies the miniature. At left, under a small arch with double columns, stands Christ (in green mantle over white tunic), gesturing toward a group of seven bearded onlookers behind three kneeling lepers. The central miracle-worker in pale blue tunic and black shoes stands slightly to the right of centre, handing a cloth or salve to a kneeling supplicant at his feet, whose arms are raised. To the right, five standing witnesses in varied green and white draperies observe, while two partially naked figures crouch in a low green tub (baptismal or healing bath). Total figures: fifteen (1 Christ in arch, 3 kneeling lepers, 3 standing behind them, 1 central healer, 5 onlookers behind him, 2 in tub). All wear long tunics or mantles with red decorative dots. Gestures of supplication and blessing dominate. Depth is indicated by overlapping heads and feet but no ground line. Gold background signifies the sacred setting.

architectural: arched niche with double columns at left

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, even creamy tone, smooth scraped surface; single quire format with consistent ruling visible under UV
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments well-preserved, gold leaf largely intact with minor abrasion at edges; slight cockling in lower margin; minimal flaking of red minium.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf in background
Confident underdrawing in brown ink visible under raking light
Fine brush stippling in flesh-tone highlights
Regular pricking and ruling for text layout

secondary_functions: Demonstration of patron’s piety and learning
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Lay noble individual for personal prayer and meditation

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This leaf, likely produced in a Parisian workshop ca. 1300–1320, reflects the shift toward vernacular devotional manuscripts intended for lay use. The use of Old French and high-quality Gothic textura suggests a commission by a noble patron seeking personal engagement with gospel miracles. The luminous gold background and restrained palette of azurite, verdigris, and minium indicate access to costly pigments and skilled illuminators, perhaps associated with the Circle of the Queen Mary Psalter tradition. The centralized composition and hierarchical scaling underscore the miracle’s theological import, while overlapping figures and white-lead highlights reveal a growing interest in spatial depth and volume. Iconographically, the depiction of Christ’s healing of lepers underscores themes of faith, purification, and intercession—key concerns in early 14th-century lay piety. Comparisons with the Bible historiale illuminate shared compositional models but this leaf’s simpler border and stronger emphasis on individual supplicants suggest a more private rather than encyclopedic function. Technically, the presence of raised gesso beneath the gold leaf and visible underdrawing aligns with contemporary Parisian illumination practices. This manuscript bridges traditional iconography and emerging tastes for personalized devotion, exemplifying the dynamic interplay between liturgical content and lay spirituality in the Gothic period.
